awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Research Experience for Undergraduates in Advanced Material Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) in Advanced Material Sciences (1) engages historically underrepresented groups (URGs) in research activities in five thematic areas, and (2) develops students’ talents and interests to fields outside their usual “window” of careers to increase enrollment and success in science and engineering fields. REU students leave knowing how to: conduct research; prepare peer-reviewed manuscripts and academic posters; and apply for graduate school. To recruit, retain, and engage URGS, the REU Site relies on three factors: (1) outreach and recruitment through nonprofit organizations that provide academic guidance and mentoring for underrepresented college students, (2) daily and ongoing mentoring and guidance of the REU students through mentors who have undergone cultural competence training, and (3) existing programs at Clemson University to engage in the professional development of URGs in and out of the laboratory. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The REU in Advanced Material Sciences engages historically URGs in research activities in five interconnected thematic areas: (1) Optical Fiber for Photonics Applications, (2) Polymers for Medical Sciences; (3) Magnetic Materials for Biomedical Applications, (4) Data Science in Computationally-Driven Materials Design, and (5) Advanced Materials in Human Health. The research projects increase the understanding in the field about property-function relationships needed to guide design of optical fibers, polymers, and magnetic nanoparticles for targeted applications and will contribute to NSF's Big Ideas on Growing Convergence Research and Harnessing the Data Revolution. Additionally, the REU Site develops students’ talents and interests in science and engineering to increase enrollment and success in students’ respective fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) in Advanced Material Sciences was conducted for 10 weeks each summer at Clemson University, beginning in the summer of 2020 through the summer of 2023. A primary goal of this project was to introduce historically underrepresented groups (HUGs) to cutting-edge STEM research in the design of optical fibers, polymers, and magnetic nanoparticles for applications in health to increase their interest in pursuing graduate education in these fields. Specifically, each summer the REU participants able to participate in materials science research from five interconnected thematic areas: (1) Optical Fiber for Photonics Applications; (2) Polymers for Medical Sciences; (3) Magnetic Materials for Biomedical Applications; (4) Data Science in Computationally-Driven Materials Design; and (5) Advanced Materials in Human Health. While each REU student focused on one specific thematic area, many of the projects had collaborations with the other thematic areas. Such collaborations enabled a broad educational experience for the REU students that helped develop their talents and interests to fields outside their usual "window" of careers. In this way, enrollment and success in STEM fields can be increased. The research projects themselves increased understanding in the field about property-function relationships needed to guide design of optical fibers, polymers, and magnetic nanoparticles for targeted applications and contributed to the NSF Big Ideas on Growing Convergence Research and Harnessing the Data Revolution. 

To achieve the goal of introducing HUGs to cutting-edge STEM research to increase their interest in pursuing graduate education in these fields, leadership team and senior personnel of the project utilized a combination of outreach in underserved statewide/national communities and extensive mentoring during each summer research experience. A comprehensive plan developed by the PI/co-PI/Program Manager's was employed to conduct each summer REU. This comprehensive plan contained three primary facets: (1) outreach and recruitment through nonprofit organizations that provides academic guidance and mentoring for underrepresented college students, (2) daily and ongoing mentoring and guidance of the students through mentors who have undergone cultural competence training, and (3) leveraging existing programs at Clemson University to engage in the professional development of female and underrepresented minorities both in and out of the laboratory. To achieve these goals, the Research Experience for Undergraduates in Advanced Material Sciences aimed to have 10 undergraduates participate in a 10-week summer research experience program each year. 

In 2020, 7 students had to be actively recruited to participate in the REU, where 14% were not from R1 or R2 universities, 57% identified as female, 14% identified as Asian or Asian American, 14% identified as Black or African American, and 14% identified as more than one race. In 2021, 16 students had to be actively recruited to participate in the REU, where 25% were not from R1 or R2 universities, 50% identified as female, 6% identified as Asian or Asian American, 13% identified as Black or African American, 13% identified as Hispanic or Latino, and 13% identified as more than one race. In 2022, 11 students had to be actively recruited to participate in the REU, where 27% were not from R1 or R2 universities, 64% identified as female, 9% identified as Asian or Asian American, and 18% identified as Black or African American. In 2023, 18 students had to be actively recruited to participate in the REU, where 50% were not from R1 or R2 universities, 67% identified as female, 6% identified as Asian or Asian American, 17% identified as Black or African American, 17% identified as Hispanic or Latino, and 6% identified as more than one race. It is important to note that COVID-19 government and university lockdowns negatively affected the number of students able to participate in the 2020 - 2023 summer REUs, where all students who participated had to be actively recruited. Due to COVID-19 government and university lockdowns affecting in person activities and access to labs, REU activities in 2020 and 2021 were primarily conducted via zoom and remotely. In 2022 and 2023, most REU activities were able to be held in person, while following COVID-19 government and university guidelines which include masks, social distancing, testing requirements, etc.

Prior to each summer REU, all mentors received cultural competence and mentoring training, as this served to enhance their ability to work with students from HUGs. Throughout the 10-week program, REU students participated in activities, including weekly seminars, check-ins, and a poster session. By the end of each summer, students developed a competitive resume, LinkedIn profile, and research poster. By participating in the REU program, students were better situated to gain employment or admittance to a STEM graduate program. After each summer program, students were able to continue their mentoring relationship throughout the following school year(s) and work with the project coordinator to apply for graduate school funding and/or develop their graduate school applications.
